t: Ecclesiastes 1
Everything Is Meaningless
The*p words of the Teacher, son of David, king in Jerusalem:
“Meaningless!*pn Meaningless!” says*ld the Teacher. “Utterly*ln meaningless! Everything*ld is meaningless.”
What*pn do people gain from all their labors at*ld which they toil under the sun?
Generations*ln come and generations go, but*ld the earth remains forever.
The*ln sun rises and the sun sets, and*ld hurries back to where it rises.
The*ln wind blows to the south and*ld turns to the north; round*ln and round it goes, ever*ld returning on its course.
All*ln streams flow into the sea, yet*ld the sea is never full. To*ln the place the streams come from, there*ld they return again.
All*ln things are wearisome, more*ld than one can say. The*ln eye never has enough of seeing, nor*ld the ear its fill of hearing.
What*ln has been will be again, what*ld has been done will be done again; there*ld is nothing new under the sun.
Is*ln there anything of which one can say, “Look!*ld This is something new”? It*ln was here already, long ago; it*ld was here before our time.
No*ln one remembers the former generations, and*ld even those yet to come will*ln not be remembered by*ld those who follow them.
Wisdom Is Meaningless
I,*p the Teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem.
I applied my mind to study and to explore by wisdom all that is done under the heavens. What a heavy burden God has laid on mankind!
I have seen all the things that are done under the sun; all of them are meaningless, a chasing after the wind.
What*pn is crooked cannot be straightened; what*ld is lacking cannot be counted.
I*p said to myself, “Look, I have increased in wisdom more than anyone who has ruled over Jerusalem before me; I have experienced much of wisdom and knowledge.”
Then I applied myself to the understanding of wisdom, and also of madness and folly, but I learned that this, too, is a chasing after the wind.
For*pn with much wisdom comes much sorrow; the*ld more knowledge, the more grief.
